title: Building big data architectures on Azure
description: Building big data architectures on Azure
summary: A big data architecture is designed to handle the ingestion, processing, and analysis of data that is too large or complex for traditional database systems.

cards.title: What is a big data architecture?
cards.summary: This article describes the logical components that fit into a big data architecture.

cards.title: Overview of data warehousing
cards.summary: A data warehouse is a central, organizational, relational repository of integrated data.

cards.title: Overview of ETL (extract, transform, and load) processing
cards.summary: ETL is a data pipeline that collects data from various sources, transforms it according to business rules, and loads it into a data store.

cards.title: Enterprise BI in Azure with SQL Data Warehouse
cards.summary: This reference architecture implements an extract, load, and transform (ELT) pipeline that moves data from SQL Server into SQL Data Warehouse for analysis.

cards.title: Automated enterprise BI with SQL Data Warehouse and Azure Data Factory
cards.summary: This reference architecture shows how to automate an ELT pipeline using Azure Data Factory.

cards.title: Hybrid ETL with existing on-premises SSIS and Azure Data Factory
cards.summary: This example discusses using existing SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) packages as part of a cloud data workflow.

cards.title: Overview of real-time processing architectures
cards.summary: Real-time processing captures steams of data in real-time and processes them with minimal latency.

cards.title: Stream processing with Azure Databricks
cards.summary: This reference architecture shows an end-to-end stream processing pipeline using Spark on Azure Databricks.

cards.title: Stream processing with Azure Stream Analytics
cards.summary: This reference architecture shows an end-to-end stream processing pipeline using Azure Stream Analytics.

cards.title: High-scale message ingestion with Event Hubs
cards.summary: Use Event Hubs to manage a workflow at very high throughput.
